title: The ladder in the chaos: An opportunity for India - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: Donald Trump’s tariffs have unleashed chaos on the world order. Will India manage to climb up the ladder of opportunity?
resumen:
Donald Trump’s tariffs have unleashed chaos on the world order.
The US is the top importer in the world, with goods worth about $3.2 trillion landing up at its ports last year―that is almost as much as the total GDP of India.
Trump announced tariffs with sweeping import duties on almost all of America’s trading partners.
Vidya Mahambare, Union Bank Chair professor of economics and director (research) at Great Lakes Institute of Management, Chennai, said that if the new tariffs are not rolled back to some extent at least, there is a high chance the US economy itself will suffer significantly and the impact will not be limited to certain export sectors or certain countries, it will have larger impact globally, including on India.
Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said that the “Liberation Day announcements by the US marks a seismic change in global order. The era of rules-based globalisation and free trade is over.”.
China’s exports to America was $83 billion more than American exports to China in 2000; last year this deficit had ballooned to nearly $300 billion.
China has imposed reciprocal tariffs.
Madhavi Arora, chief economist with Emkay Global, said that because it’s a retaliation from the US across the globe, the retaliation to the US will also be across the globe.
Prime Minister Narendra Modi sealed a deal to double bilateral trade to $500 billion by the end of this decade.
The countries might sign a bilateral trade agreement (BTA) by this autumn.
Ankit Jaipuria, co-founder of ZYOD, an export-oriented textile sector manufacturing firm, said that if India has an advantage in the near term with a less tariff than other exporting countries, to become more competitive the government should provide production-linked incentives and capital incentives to expand the manufacturing supply base.
Mrunmayee Joglekar, analyst at Asit C. Mehta Investment Intermediates, said that the Indian auto component industry generates 30 per cent of its revenues from exports, of which nearly 30 per cent is from the US.
Panckaj N. Umrania, executive director at KND, a steel maker, said that duty on Chinese steel in the US was 25 per cent; now it has been increased to 54 per cent.
Arora said that there will be a whole lot of simultaneous negotiations and that India has to be nimble, more strategic, and not just with the US and existing trade partners, but with new ones.
While India’s industrial capacity utilisation averages above 70 per cent for big industries, it can be as low as 33 per cent for small scale units.
Jaipuria said that what India needs to work upon is a focused process-oriented approach where it can provide cost benefit, cost efficiencies and reliability to global players.

title: How India can tackle Donald Trump’s tariff tantrums - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: Former vice chairman of NITI Aayog, Rajiv Kumar, explains how the Donald Trump-induced tariff tantrums could affect India and outlines ways in which India should respond ...
resumen:
Rajiv Kumar, former vice chairman of NITI Aayog, explains how the Donald Trump-induced tariff tantrums could affect India and outlines ways in which India should respond.

India should not try and lead or even join any attempt for the restoration of the WTO institutional regime.

India should neither contemplate retaliating nor should it go ‘cap in hand’ looking for charitable discounts under the veneer of a bilateral trade agreement.

India should give up the myth that India benefits from a ‘strong rupee’.

The Reserve Bank in collaboration with the Central government should let the rupee depreciate sufficiently to absorb some of the hike in prices of our export goods that will happen as a result of the higher tariffs.

India should also try and put in place robust export promotion measures, which could be made an integral part of the production-linked incentive scheme.

Each state government may be encouraged to formulate its own export promotion policies.

These state-specific export promotion policies should now focus on the space opened up in the US market.

The Central government should partner with and assist state governments to identify ‘Anchor Investor’ in select sectors.

An in-depth review of these export promotion councils and subsequently assigning them specific outcome-based key performance indicators are required.

India and its states need to get their act together.

We need to bring the governments, private industry and the academia on the same platform for designing and implementing a robust and dynamic set of state specific export promotion policies.

The author is chairman of Pahlé India Foundation and former vice chairman of NITI Aayog.

title: The world economy on the edge of the razor; Where does the Duel of Trump and the object come from? - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: The US -China tariff war has entered a new phase in the light of Trump's recent decisions as well as Beijing's decisive reaction; A stage that endangers the economy of the two countries but also the ...
resumen:
The US-China tariff war has entered a new phase due to Trump's recent decisions and Beijing's reaction, endangering the economies of both countries and the stability of the world economy.

US President Donald Trump announced a 5% baseline tariff on all imported goods on April 2 (April 5). The EU faced a 5% tariff, while countries like Vietnam (2%), Bangladesh (2%), Taiwan (2%), Japan (2%), and Lesotho (2%) were also affected. China responded with tariffs exceeding 100%. Trump retreated from tariffs on over 5 countries for 6 days but increased tariffs on Chinese goods to 5%. China increased customs tariffs on American goods by 5%. The White House announced total tariffs on imports of Chinese goods up to 2%. China has put a large US company on the list of unreliable institutions and increased economic cooperation with the European Union and the Southeast Asian Union (ASEAN).

The tariff war has affected the American and Chinese economies. In the United States, economic growth has slowed, with real GDP dropping by about half a percent in the first half of the year. US consumers have faced rising prices, costing an additional $2 annually per household. American farmers have faced a sharp decline in demand, with soybean exports declining by less than half. The automotive industry has faced increased costs and lost export markets. Great market analysts have warned that the continuation of this trend could enter the US economy by the end of the year.

China's economic growth has reached 5% this year, the lowest in the last two decades. Reducing exports to the United States, dropping domestic demand, and reducing private sector investment are key factors in this downtrend. The Yuan’s value has fallen to its lowest level since year 6. Millions of Chinese workers in export-oriented industries have been threatened by unemployment. China has tried to reduce its dependence on the US market by expanding its export markets to other countries such as members of ASEAN, Africa, and Latin America.

The tariff war between the United States and China has had significant impacts on the world trade process. The increase in tariffs has impaired the free flow of goods and capital, and global supply chains, especially in technology, automotive, medicine, and consumer goods, have become unstable. One of the most important consequences of these tensions is the increase in global inflation. This war has slowed global economic growth. The IMF and the World Bank have reported that these tensions could reduce the world’s GDP by up to a few percent.

The tariff war has accelerated the “economic worldwide” process or decline in world trade dependence. Countries have become more inclined to boost their domestic production or find new business partners. The impact of the tariff war is not just economic. These wars can weaken international organizations such as the World Trade Organization (WTO), exacerbate regional competitions, and create the basis for future political and military confrontation.

Observers believe that continuing or exacerbating trade tensions between the United States and China is a profound threat to the global economy and geopolitical order. A full-fledged trade war can reduce the world’s GDP in the long run. Raw material exporters suffer the most damage from this situation. Severe inflation, instability of financial markets, increased economic pressure on consumers, policy-making in economic decisions, and even the possibility of expanding conflicts to non-economic areas are among the worrying consequences of such a crisis.

Experts believe that the parties should return to the negotiating table and move towards multilateral agreements with European, Asian, and international institutions. Supporting the affected industries through financial facilitation policies and diversification to global supply chains can reduce the risk of over-dependence on a particular country.

title: Apple has few incentives to start making iPhones in US, despite Trump’s trade war with China - (Published Apr 12, 2025)
content: President Trump’s administration has been predicting its barrage of tariffs targeting China will push Apple into manufacturing the iPhone in the US. But that’s an unlikely scenario.
resumen:
President Donald Trump’s administration has been predicting its barrage of tariffs targeting China will push Apple into manufacturing the iPhone in the United States for the first time.

The disincentives for Apple shifting its production domestically include a complex supply chain that it began building in China during the 1990s. It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build new plants in the US, and then confront Apple with economic forces that could triple the price of an iPhone, threatening to torpedo sales of its marquee product.

US tariffs are now standing at 145% on products made in China.

The Trump administration said late Friday it was excluding electronics, including smartphones, from the current reciprocal tariffs. But it still could levy new or different tariffs on electronics at a later date.

Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives estimated that the current $1,000 price tag for an iPhone made in China, or India, would soar to more than $3,000 if production shifted to the US. He believes that moving production domestically likely couldn’t be done until, at the earliest, 2028.

Apple didn’t respond to a request for comment Wednesday. Apple CEO Tim Cook is scheduled to field questions from analysts during a quarterly conference call to discuss the company’s financial results and strategy on May 1.

Apple’s stock price has dropped by 15% and lowered the company’s market value by $500 billion since Trump began increasing tariffs on April 2.

Apple is widely expected to eventually raise the prices on iPhones and other popular products if the tariffs hold.

Forrester Research analyst Dipanjan Chatterjee said Apple continues to reap huge profit margins from the revenue generated by the subscriptions and other services tied to its product. That division collected $96 billion in revenue during Apple’s last fiscal year.

Apple tried to appease Trump in February by announcing plans to spend $500 billion and hire 20,000 people in the US through 2028, but none of it was tied to making an iPhone domestically.

White House Press Secretary Karoline Levitt pointed to Apple’s investment promise as evidence that the company thinks it could be done.

US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick predicted tariffs would force a manufacturing shift during an April 6 appearance on a CBS news program.

During a 2017 appearance at a conference in China, Cook expressed doubt about whether the US labor pool had enough workers with the vocational skills required.

Trump also tried to pressure Apple, to no avail, into shifting iPhone production to the US during his first term as president. The administration ultimately exempted the iPhone from the tariffs he imposed on China back then. Apple had announced a commitment to invest $350 billion in the US.

Trump’s first-term tariffs on China also prompted Apple to begin a process that led to some of its current iPhones being made in India and some of its other products being manufactured in Vietnam.

Cook took the president on a 2019 tour of a Texas plant where Apple had been assembling some of its Mac computers since 2013.

title: Trump’s tariffs have launched global trade wars. Here’s a timeline of how we got here - (Published 17 hour(s), 44 minute(s) ago)
content: Long-threatened tariffs from U.S. President Donald Trump have plunged the country into trade wars abroad — all while on-again, off-again new levies continue to escalate uncertainty.
resumen:
U.S. President Donald Trump's tariffs have plunged the country into trade wars abroad, escalating uncertainty. Trump launched a trade war during his first term, targeting China with taxes on most of its goods, leading to retaliatory tariffs from Beijing on U.S. products. Trump also used the threat of tariffs to renegotiate the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement in 2020. Economists stress greater consequences on businesses and economies worldwide under Trump’s more sweeping tariffs, with higher prices likely for consumers.

Timeline:

*   **January 20:** Trump is sworn into office, promising to "tariff and tax foreign countries." He plans to create the External Revenue Service. He expects to put 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico starting Feb. 1, while declining to immediately flesh out plans for taxing Chinese imports.
*   **January 26:** Trump threatens 25% tariffs on all Colombia imports and other retaliatory measures after President Gustavo Petro’s rejects two U.S. military aircraft carrying migrants to the country. Petro announces a retaliatory 25% increase in Colombian tariffs on U.S. goods, but Colombia later reversed its decision.
*   **February 1:** Trump signs an executive order to impose tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada, and China – 10% on all imports from China and 25% on imports from Mexico and Canada starting Feb. 4.
*   **February 3:** Trump agrees to a 30-day pause on his tariff threats against Mexico and Canada.
*   **February 4:** Trump’s new 10% tariffs on all Chinese imports to the U.S. go into effect. China retaliates the same day by announcing countermeasures, including new duties on American goods and an anti-monopoly investigation into Google. China’s 15% tariffs on coal and liquefied natural gas products, and a 10% levy on crude oil, agricultural machinery and large-engine cars imported from the U.S., take effect Feb. 10.
*   **February 10:** Trump announces plans to hike steel and aluminum tariffs starting March 12. He removes the exemptions from his 2018 tariffs on steel, meaning that all steel imports will be taxed at a minimum of 25%, and also raises his 2018 aluminum tariffs from 10% to 25%.
*   **February 13:** Trump announces a plan for “reciprocal” tariffs.
*   **February 25:** Trump signs an executive order instructing the Commerce Department to consider whether a tariff on imported copper is needed to protect national security.
*   **March 1:** Trump signs an executive order instructing the Commerce Department to consider whether tariffs on lumber and timber are also needed to protect national security.
*   **March 4:** Trump’s 25% tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico go into effect, though he limits the levy to 10% on Canadian energy. He also doubles the tariff on all Chinese imports to 20%. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announces tariffs on more than $100 billion of American goods over the course of 21 days. Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum says her country would respond with its own retaliatory tariffs on U.S. goods. China imposes tariffs of up to 15% on a wide array of key U.S. farm exports, set to take effect March 10.
*   **March 5:** Trump grants a one-month exemption on his new tariffs impacting goods from Mexico and Canada for U.S. automakers.
*   **March 6:** Trump postpones 25% tariffs on many imports from Mexico and some imports from Canada for a month. He still plans to impose “reciprocal” tariffs starting on April 2.
*   **March 10:** China’s retaliatory 15% tariffs on key American farm products take effect.
*   **March 12:** Trump’s new tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports go into effect. The European Union takes retaliatory trade action promising new duties on U.S. industrial and farm products. Canada announces plans to impose retaliatory tariffs worth Canadian $29.8 billion ($20.7 billion) on U.S. imports, set to go into effect March 13.
*   **March 13:** Trump threatens a 200% tariff on European wine, Champagne and spirits if the European Union goes forward with its previously-announced plans for a 50% tariff on American whiskey.
*   **March 24:** Trump says he will place a 25% tariff on all imports from any country that buys oil or gas from Venezuela, in addition to imposing new tariffs on the South American country itself, starting April 2.
*   **March 26:** Trump says he is placing 25% tariffs on auto imports, starting April 3.
*   **April 2:** Trump announces his long-promised “reciprocal” tariffs – declaring a 10% baseline tax on imports across the board starting April 5, as well as higher rates for dozens of nations that run trade surpluses with the U.S. to take effect April 9. Among those steeper levies, Trump says the U.S. will now charge a 34% tax on imports from China, a 20% tax on imports from the European Union, 25% on South Korea, 24% on Japan and 32% on Taiwan.
*   **April 3:** Trump’s previously-announced auto tariffs begin. Prime Minister Mark Carney says that Canada will match the 25% levies with a tariff on vehicles imported from the U.S.
*   **April 4:** China announces plans to impose a 34% tariff on imports of all U.S. products beginning April 10, matching Trump’s new “reciprocal” tariff on Chinese goods, as part of a flurry of retaliatory measures.
*   **April 5:** Trump’s 10% minimum tariff on nearly all countries and territories takes effect.
*   **April 9:** Trump’s higher “reciprocal” rates go into effect. His administration says it will suspend most of these higher rates for 90 days, while maintaining the recently-imposed 10% levy on nearly all global imports. Trump says he will now raise those import taxes to 125% “effective immediately” on China. China upped its retaliation prior to this announcement — vowing to tax American goods at 84% starting April 10. Canada’s counter tariffs on auto imports also take effect. EU member states vote to approve their own retaliatory levies on 20.9 billion euros ($23 billion) of U.S. goods.
*   **April 10:** The White House clarifies that Trump’s previously-announced 125% figure for tariffs against China is actually 145%, once his previous 20% fentanyl tariffs are accounted for. The EU

title: Why Morgan Stanley says Nvidia stock is still a 'top pick' under Trump's looming tariffs threats - (Published 17 hour(s), 7 minute(s) ago)
content: Nvidia is one of the firms "more protected" from Trump's tariffs, Morgan Stanley said this week.
resumen: Morgan Stanley says Nvidia stock is still a "top pick" even under Trump's looming tariffs threats. The bank believes the impact of tariffs on Nvidia's business could be "minimal." Demand for Nvidia's chips is strong, and the company could work its supply chain around duties. Semiconductors were left out of Trump's April 2 tariff plan. Even if tariffs are implemented on chips, Nvidia could face "fairly minimal" consequences, in part because demand for its chips is so strong and because the firm has some flexibility with its supply chains. Morgan Stanley calls Nvidia its "Top Pick." Nvidia reported record revenue of $39.2 billion over the last quarter, up 78% year-over-year. CEO Jensen Huang said that demand for Blackwell, Nvidia's latest chip, has been "insane." Morgan Stanley analysts added that industry contacts are generally unconcerned by the tariffs, because demand is strong, Blackwell is sold out, and demand is quite price insensitive. Most builds for Nvidia's GB200 platform may be in North America and not subject to tariffs. Most of the framework for some of Nvidia's products may already be in North America. Hon Hai, one of Nvidia's partners, said it would boost its capacity for GB200 severs this year, which the bank said could be completed in a facility in Mexico. Bianca boards, one component of the GB200 platform, could also potentially be built in Mexico. Other Nvidia partners, like ZT systems, could also potentially build GB200s in facilities in the US. Nvidia shares have been hit harder than the overall market since Trump plowed ahead with his latest tariff plan in early April. Shares dropped as much as 14% in the first two trading days following Liberation Day, compared to the S&P 500, which dropped as much as 10% over that timeframe.

En 2024, las exportaciones hacia Estados Unidos alcanzaron los US$14.336 millones, lo que representó el 28,9 % del total de las exportaciones colombianas a nivel mundial.

Desde la entrada en vigor del Acuerdo de Promoción Comercial (APC) en 2012, estas exportaciones han consolidado una relación comercial sólida.

title: Trump tariff nightmare continues to plague markets as US dollar plunges on trade war, recession fears - (Published 23 hour(s), 6 minute(s) ago)
content: Singapore stocks headed for an 8.5 per cent plunge for the week as US-China trade war intensifies. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: Singapore stocks plunged 8.2 per cent this week and the US dollar sank as investors struggled to deal with an intensifying trade war between the United States and China. A midweek respite after US President Donald Trump announced a 90-day timeout on his tariff barrage failed to last. The Asia markets rally on April 10 turned the next day into what traders call “sell the rip”. Analysts said that while the tariff pause and the start of bilateral negotiations between the US and some trading partners was a welcome development, it does not give enough clarity on the risks that listed companies and the global economy are facing from the hit to consumers and the damage to supply chains. The pause does not address the US-China tit-for-tat trade war. China struck back against US tariffs by raising its levies on US goods to 125 per cent from 84 per cent. Mr Trump on April 10 raised duties on China to a staggering 145 per cent. Beijing said it would ignore any further moves by Mr Trump because it no longer makes economic sense for importers to buy from America, and any more US tariffs “will become a joke in the history of world economy”. Ms Erica York, a vice-president at the Tax Foundation’s Centre for Federal Tax Policy, told CNBC that Mr Trump’s tariffs essentially cut off most trade with China. Mr Eugene Leow, senior rates strategist at DBS Bank, said: “As things stand, the worst of the sentiment deterioration could be behind us, with market participants now watching to see what would happen in the next 90 days.” Singapore’s Straits Times Index closed down 1.8 per cent at 3,512.53 points on April 11 before news that China announced its retaliation. The battered Singapore stock market – which suffered its worst day since the 2008 global financial crisis this week – reflects investor worries over the threat to Singapore’s trade-driven economy from a potential tariff-induced global recession. Singapore is a key financial and transshipment hub, and a critical supplier of semiconductors, pharmaceuticals, petrochemicals and transport engineering goods such as aircraft engines, and offshore rigs and platforms. The semiconductor and pharmaceutical sectors – which together account for the bulk of Singapore exports to the US – are also in Mr Trump’s tariff cross hairs. Around the world, markets were flashing red as steep sell-offs hit US assets – stocks, dollar and bonds – on recession fears. The US dollar extended its slide on April 11 as the escalating tariff war continued to undermine the currency’s status as a safe haven in times of stress. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, which measures the greenback against six main peers, fell 1.2 per cent, after sinking 1.5 per cent the day before, its biggest plunge in three years. Against the Singapore currency, the US dollar tumbled 1 per cent to 1.3172 as at 5.44pm local time. At this level, the Singapore dollar has gained 3.1 per cent to date this year. The currency has fallen more than 7 per cent since Mr Trump’s inauguration in January, and more than 2 per cent since he unveiled global tariffs on April 2. The sell-off in US Treasuries picked up pace on April 11, with the 10-year note yield rising to 4.45 per cent, gaining about 45 basis points in the week, the biggest increase since 2001, LSEG data showed. Analysts said that the US and China, with a combined gross domestic product of US$46 trillion (S$61 trillion), are locked in a game of chicken in which no one will be left unscathed. Ms Selena Ling, chief economist and head of global markets research and strategy at OCBC Bank, said: “The tariff drama is not over by any means.” Dr Chua Hak Bin, regional co-head of macro research at Maybank, said: “The US-China tariff wall has climbed to a prohibitive level that will almost dry up all bilateral China-US trade activity.” For Asian businesses highly integrated into Chinese supply chains, the pain is deep and ongoing. Original equipment parts exporter Outsource Asia Industries told The Straits Times that its US business has fallen into limbo. The Singapore firm, which exports construction safety equipment from its partner’s factory in China to the US and Canada, said its US customers have asked to delay shipments that are not already en route for now. On April 14, the Ministry of Trade and Industry will likely cut its forecast for Singapore’s 2025 economic growth from its current 1 per cent to 3 per cent range, when it releases the first-quarter advance estimates. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has warned that growth this year will be “significantly impacted” and Singapore could tip into a recession. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to further reduce the pace of the Singapore dollar’s trade-weighted appreciation, given the Trump tariffs’ risks to growth.

title: China hits back at Trump tariff hike, turmoil rings recession alarm - (Published 18 hour(s), 43 minute(s) ago)
content: China’s retaliation deepened the economic turmoil from Trump’s tariffs, sending markets down and leaving foreign leaders uncertain how to respond to the major trade disruption.
resumen:
China increased its tariffs on US imports to 125% on Friday, in response to US President Donald Trump’s decision to hike duties on Chinese goods.

China’s retaliation intensified the economic turmoil unleashed by Trump’s tariffs, with markets tumbling further.

Adam Hetts, global head of multi-asset at Janus Henderson, said the recession risk is much higher now than a couple of weeks ago.

The tit-for-tat increases stand to make goods trade between the world’s two largest economies impossible, analysts say. That commerce was worth more than $650 billion in 2024.

Global stocks fell, the dollar slid and a sell-off in US government bonds picked up pace on Friday. Gold scaled a record high.

Trump ratcheted up tariffs on Chinese imports, raising them effectively to 145%.

China hit back with its own new tariffs on Friday, with the finance ministry saying Trump’s new tariffs were “completely unilateral bullying and coercion.”

Beijing indicated that this would be the last time it matched the US, should Trump take his duties any higher.

The finance ministry said that even if the US continues to impose even higher tariffs, it would no longer have any economic significance.

UBS analysts called China’s declaration that it would not retaliate to any further tariff increases “an acknowledgement that trade between the two countries has essentially been completely severed.”

Trump said he thought the United States could make a deal with China and said he respected Chinese President Xi Jinping.

Xi told Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez during a meeting in Beijing on Friday that China and the European Union should “jointly oppose unilateral acts of bullying,” in a clear swipe at Trump’s tariff policies.

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said striking deals with other countries would bring certainty.

The US and Vietnam have agreed to begin formal trade talks.

Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has set up a trade task force that hopes to visit Washington next week.

French President Emmanuel Macron said Trump’s decision for a 90-day suspension on tariffs gave room for only a “fragile pause.”

The euro extended its rise on Friday, reaching its highest in over three years versus the dollar. It also rose to an 11-year high against the Chinese yuan in the offshore market.

EU finance ministers brainstormed on Friday how to use the pause to get a trade deal with Washington.

The EU said on Thursday it would pause its first counter-tariffs.

The European Central Bank will meet next week to discuss how tariff chaos will change policymakers’ thinking on rate cuts.

title: What to Know About Who Pays the Higher Costs of Trump’s Tariffs - (Published 12 hour(s), 58 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump’s trade policies will make imports more expensive and calculating and paying the tariffs more complicated.
resumen:
President Trump’s latest tariffs are about to become an unavoidable and expensive reality for American businesses and for people who rely on foreign goods.

Shoppers buying clothes from retailers in China may soon pay more than twice as much, now that a special exemption for lower-value imports is disappearing.

Companies involved in international trade must now make even more complicated calculations to decide how much they owe in tariffs.

Imports from China have been hit with tariffs of 145 percent. That means for every $100 worth of goods a business buys from that country, it has to pay $145 to the federal government.

Goods from most other countries have a new 10 percent tax, though that could rise if the countries do not reach trade agreements with the United States by July.

There are separate tariffs on cars, steel and aluminum.

Mr. Trump has also said he wants to impose new tariffs on pharmaceuticals and computer chips.

American businesses importing the goods pay the tariffs to the Customs and Border Protection when goods enter the United States.

Importers may pass some or all of the cost of the tariff to consumers through higher prices.

Most importers employ customs brokers who calculate the tariffs owed based on the goods’ value and where they were exported from.

Payments are made electronically, from the bank accounts of either importers or the brokers, who later recoup the money from their clients.

The tariffs end up at the Treasury Department.

Trade rules allow for some leeway. Importers who realize they have made a mistake and inform Customs and Border Protection are usually allowed to pay what they owe, plus interest.

Mr. Trump’s recent executive orders on metals tariffs were stricter than that. The order said Customs and Border Protection could impose much higher monetary penalties if importers misclassified goods.

Customs and Border Protection’s systems are already showing signs of strain.

On Friday, the agency said importers had not been able to submit tariffs owed on certain goods.

Customs and Border Protection said it was releasing the goods affected by this problem and allowing importers to submit their customs duties later.

Countries that don’t strike trade deals with the United States by July may face higher tariffs, and Mr. Trump may suddenly decide to introduce new tariffs.

U.S. imports from China totaled $439 billion last year.

title: Consumer sentiment plunges as tariffs send inflation expectations soaring - (Published 14 hour(s), 50 minute(s) ago)
content: Recent economic data showed that, as of March, job creation remained solid and inflation pressures were easing. U.S. wholesale prices fell in March by the most since October 2023, restrained by energy ...
resumen:
U.S. consumer sentiment tumbled to the second-weakest reading on record while short- and long-term inflation expectations soared to multidecade highs on growing tariff concerns.

The preliminary April sentiment index slid 6.2 points to 50.8, according to the University of Michigan, below economists’ forecasts. Aside from a 50 reading in June 2022, that was the lowest in surveys dating back to the 1970s.

The results were based on interviews from March 25 through April 8, prior to President Donald Trump’s Wednesday announcement of a 90-day pause on higher tariffs for dozens of U.S. trading partners. Duties on China have been subsequently raised to 145%.

Respondents were also more pessimistic on the outlook for the job market, with the share of consumers expecting higher unemployment in the coming year rising to the highest since 2009.

Respondents’ saw the odds of losing their job in the next five years at the highest since July 2020. Income expectations also deteriorated.

Consumers expect prices to rise at an annual rate of 4.4% over the next five to 10 years, the highest since 1991 and up from 4.1% a month ago, according to the report. They saw costs rising 6.7% in the coming year, the highest since 1981. In March, year-ahead inflation expectations stood at 5%.

About two-thirds of consumers spontaneously mentioned tariffs during interviews for the survey, the university said. Since the end of January, the sentiment index has declined nearly 21 points.

The survey showed the current conditions gauge fell to 56.5 from 63.8, while the expectations index decreased to 47.2 — the weakest since 1980. Consumers’ outlook of their financial situation decreased in April to a fresh record low.

title: Fed’s Williams warns Trump’s tariff plan could push inflation to 4%, slow US growth - (Published 13 hour(s), 9 minute(s) ago)
content: Donald Trump’s tariff policies could sharply raise inflation and stall US economic growth, New York Federal Reserve President John Williams warned. He projected inflation could climb to 3.5–4% this ...
resumen:
Donald Trump’s tariff policies could sharply raise inflation and stall US economic growth, New York Federal Reserve President John Williams warned. He projected inflation could climb to 3.5–4% this year, well above the Fed’s 2% target, driven by trade uncertainties and declining consumer and business confidence.

New York Federal Reserve President John Williams has issued a stark warning that former President Donald Trump’s renewed tariff policies could accelerate US inflation to as high as 4% this year while also slowing economic growth and rising unemployment.

In prepared remarks to the Puerto Rico Chamber of Commerce, Williams said the US is experiencing “a pervasive sense of uncertainty,” citing a notable decline in consumer and business sentiment.

Williams said the economy’s strong start to the year is likely to give way toward something less favourable.

Williams projected inflation to reach between 3.5% and 4% in 2025 — well above the Fed’s 2% target and the current 2.5% annualised reading of the Fed’s preferred personal consumption expenditures (PCE) index.

He predicted GDP growth would likely fall to “somewhat below 1%” — a steep drop from last year’s pace — while unemployment could rise from the current 4.2% to between 4.5% and 5%.

Williams noted that he remains committed to getting inflation back to the Fed’s 2% target.

Williams said monetary policy is in the right place to manage those risks as best we can and its “modestly restrictive” level is the right one given the current level of inflation.

The Fed’s benchmark interest rate is currently set in the 4.25%-4.50% range.

title: What's next for Trump's tariffs? Where the trade war goes from here after sudden retreat. - (Published 19 hour(s), 7 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump said he would revive the tariffs he paused if countries do not agree to trade deals. Here's where the tariffs talk goes from here.
resumen:
President Donald Trump said he would revive the reciprocal tariffs that he paused for 90 days if countries do not agree to satisfactory trade deals.

Trump paused massive reciprocal tariffs on April 9 but left in place a 10% universal tariff rate for all imports.

Trump hit China with a 125% reciprocal tariff. That raises the total tariff rate on China to 145% when combined with previously imposed tariffs.

Trump suggested the 10% baseline tariff could be reduced for certain countries through negotiations.

Trump convened a Cabinet meeting a day after announcing a 90-day pause on ‘reciprocal’ tariffs, with the exception of China.

Trump also left open the possibility he could decide to extend the pause beyond 90 days.

Trump's top economic aides have initiated negotiations with about 75 countries to discuss tariffs and other trade policies.

White House officials have cited progress with Japan, South Korea and Vietnam, but no agreements have been reached.

Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick told Trump at the Cabinet meeting, describing the response as "incredible."

Trump has argued the steep tariffs are needed to cut trade deficits with other countries, particularly China, and rejuvenate the United States' manufacturing base.

Even with Trump's pause on reciprocal tariffs, his administration has still imposed substantial import taxes that economists warn could spike consumer prices and lead to an economic downturn.

Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics, put the odds of a recession at about 60% after Trump's move.

Trump raised the tariffs on imports from China after Beijing hit the United States with 84% retaliatory tariffs.

Trump did not say when asked whether Chinese President Xi Jinping has reached out to discuss trade policy.

Trump's industry-specific 25% tariffs on steel, aluminum and auto imports remain in effect.

Trump has also vowed to place a "a major tariff" on pharmaceuticals.

Previously imposed 25% tariffs on certain goods from Mexico and Canada are still in place.

The stock market plunged again April 10, one day after stocks soared after Trump's announcement of the pause.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent downplayed the market drop.

Bessent said that as the administration negotiates with countries, the United States will “end up in quite great certainty over the next 90 days on tariffs.”

resumen:
British diners are bad at complaining in restaurants. Experts including chefs, an etiquette adviser, and the King's former butler share tips on how to complain.

Brian Mcelderry, a chef with almost 50 years of experience, says the UK is "notoriously very, very bad" at complaining. In the US, customers are upfront and confident, and in France, people know how to complain.

Experts say steak is the number one dish Britons mistakenly complain about.

Laura Windsor, an etiquette expert, says the best way to complain is with patience, understanding, and eye contact. Discreetly speaking to the waiter away from the table is more effective.

Chef Mcelderry says polite customers are more likely to receive a complimentary dish, drink, or discount.

Grant Harold, a former butler to the King, says eating more than a few mouthfuls before complaining is "completely unacceptable". If a bottle of wine has been tasted, there's no turning back.

Daniel Thompson, general manager at the Thurlestone Hotel, says complaining after three-quarters of a meal is unacceptable.

Chef Mcelderry says the average three-course meal should last one hour and 30 minutes, so if you're waiting more than half an hour, expect a discount. Harold says it's standard to get a free bottle of wine if a meal is really late.

Windsor says Britons should be proactive when complaining.

Tipping is voluntary, and if the service isn't up to standard, tell the waiter and ask for the gratuity to be removed.

title: Guerra comercial entre EE.UU. y China genera incertidumbre: ¿cómo impacta en la soja paraguaya? - (Published 10 hour(s), 33 minute(s) ago)
content: La creciente tensión comercial entre China y Estados Unidos, a partir de la imposición de aranceles, está repercutiendo en el mercado de las principales commodities agrícolas, según analizó la Cámara ...
resumen:
La creciente tensión comercial entre China y Estados Unidos, a partir de la imposición de aranceles, está repercutiendo en el mercado de las principales commodities agrícolas, según analizó la Cámara Paraguaya de Exportadores y Comercializadores de Cereales y Oleaginosas. Este escenario desata preocupación sobre a cómo se cotizarán en el mercado internacional rubros como la soja, que presentaban una tendencia a la baja.

La guerra comercial entre EE. UU. y China genera incertidumbre en el mercado agrícola global.

La Cámara Paraguaya de Exportadores y Comercializadores de Cereales y Oleaginosas (Capeco) analizó este viernes cómo impactará la guerra comercial entre China y Estados Unidos en el comercio agrícola mundial.

Desde el miércoles 9 de abril, entró a regir un nuevo arancel impuesto por Estados Unidos a las importaciones provenientes de más de 60 países, siendo China el principal objetivo de la medida.

El impacto también se sintió en el mercado de Chicago, donde la soja encabezó las caídas de precios, con una merma del 4,4% en comparación con el cierre del 4 de abril y del 28 de marzo.

Luego de Trump anunciase una pausa de 90 días para los aranceles adicionales, se observó una leve recuperación en los futuros agrícolas, según el gremio local. La soja, de vencimiento en mayo de 2025, se incrementó en 2% respecto al 8 de abril pasado y alcanzó los 372,1 dólares por tonelada por impulso de la sostenida demanda China y las exenciones otorgadas a países en proceso de negociación.

El nuevo aumento arancelario elevó la carga total impuesta por EE.UU hasta el 145%, con efecto inmediato.

Brasil podría encontrar una oportunidad estratégica para aumentar sus volúmenes de exportación al gigante asiático.

El conflicto comercial llevaría a China a buscar alternativas a EE. UU. como proveedor de granos y oleaginosas y redirigir su demanda hacia nuestra región, lo que podría abrir la posibilidad de una reconfiguración del comercio agrícola mundial.

Sonia Tomassone, asesora de Comercio Exterior de Capeco, explicó que este escenario afectará principalmente a Paraguay en “la variación de los precios internacionales” de la soja.

Estados Unidos tiene un stock alto de soja que ahora, con la guerra de aranceles, no va a poder vender a China. Esta dinámica podría significar “un bajón” de precios internacionales, cuyas fluctuaciones ya se están notando en las cotizaciones de Chicago.

La cotización actual está muy por debajo de los 400 dólares por tonelada, cuando en periodos anteriores llegó a alcanzar incluso los 600 dólares por tonelada.

Las exportaciones de soja a Estados Unidos son “muy puntuales”, por lo que la decisión de Donald Trump de imponer un arancel global del 10% a las importaciones no tendrá mayor impacto para este rubro particular.

title: La oportunidad que ya empezamos a desperdiciar - (Published 23 hour(s), 47 minute(s) ago)
content: Un ejemplo sencillo es el área de vestuario y textiles, con Vietnam. Inicialmente, le pusieron un arancel mayor, lo que volvía a los productos guatemaltecos, como por arte de magia, más competitivos.
resumen:
El panorama de los aranceles continúa cambiando, pasando del anuncio del “Día de la Liberación” de Donald Trump, con un arancel del 10 por ciento, a la “tregua arancelaria”, sin cambios significativos para Guatemala en términos absolutos, pero sí relativos.

Se debe prestar atención a las barreras no arancelarias o atenerse a las consecuencias.

Un ejemplo es el área de vestuario y textiles con Vietnam, donde inicialmente se impuso un arancel mayor, pero ahora la situación es similar.

A Guatemala le impusieron el 10 por ciento porque era lo mínimo, y no por una “fórmula”.

Guatemala tiene “superávit comercial” con Estados Unidos.

Existen muchas “barreras no arancelarias”, como la discrecionalidad de la SAT, la corrupción de las aduanas y la tramitología absurda.

La oficina del representante de Comercio -USTR- lleva años quejándose de lo mismo.

Las quejas de las empresas estadounidenses son similares a las de las empresas guatemaltecas.

En negocios con poco margen, si los vietnamitas logran bajar el arancel al 5 por ciento, mientras Guatemala lo mantiene al 10, algunas empresas podrían salir del mercado y perderse miles de empleos.

Los primeros pasos se pueden dar inmediatamente, con decisiones del Ejecutivo y, en algunos casos, del Legislativo.

La receta es eliminar todos los aranceles y reducir las barreras no arancelarias, incluyendo eliminar el IVA a las importaciones y todos los permisos y registros que no sean imposibles de eliminar.

Esto debe aplicarse a todos los países, no solo a Estados Unidos, para cerrar las aduanas y acabar con la corrupción.

Con esos cambios, se estaría en una mejor posición para negociar la reducción arancelaria.

Escrito por: Jorge Jacobs, empresario, conductor de programas de opinión en Libertópolis y analista del servicio Analyze. Fue director ejecutivo del Centro de Estudios Económico-Sociales (CEES).

title: Líderes de América Latina prometen unidad ante la guerra comercial de Trump en la cumbre Celac - (Published 15 hour(s), 47 minute(s) ago)
content: La cumbre de la Celac culminó este miércoles en Honduras con promesas de unidad de América Latina y el Caribe frente a la guerra comercial del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump.Once gobernantes d ...
resumen:
La cumbre de la Celac culminó en Honduras con promesas de unidad de América Latina y el Caribe frente a la guerra comercial del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump.

Once gobernantes de izquierda acudieron a este cónclave, entre ellos Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva de Brasil, Claudia Sheinbaum de México y Gustavo Petro de Colombia.

El mandatario brasileño dijo que "los aranceles arbitrarios desestabilizan la economía internacional y elevan los precios" y añadió que "la historia nos enseña que las guerras comerciales no tienen vencedores".

La mandataria anfitriona, Xiomara Castro, sostuvo que los países latinoamericanos no pueden "seguir caminando separados cuando el mundo se reorganiza", mientras "Estados Unidos redibuja su mapa económico sin preguntarse qué pueblos quedan atrás".

Petro advirtió que no se debe caer "en la trampa de resolver los problemas solos" y afirmó que "nos van a destruir o nos vamos a autodestruir".

La mandataria mexicana dijo que "son momentos de cambios profundos en el comercio mundial que afectan a nuestros países" y añadió que "hoy más que nunca es un buen momento para reconocer que América Latina y el Caribe requieren de unidad y solidaridad de sus gobiernos y de sus pueblos y fortalecer una mayor integración regional".

Colombia asumió la presidencia rotativa de la Celac, con un llamado de Petro a ayudar a Haití, Cuba y Venezuela.

Petro dijo que trabajará para formar "grupos de trabajo voluntarios [...] hacia Haití y su fortalecimiento democrático, [y] hacia la superación concreta de los bloqueos impuestos a Cuba y Venezuela".

Estos grupos deben tener "objetivos concretos a alcanzar" en aspectos de superación de conflictos, de integración y profundización democrática.

Impulsará proyectos para la conservación de la Amazonía, la inteligencia artificial, una interconexión eléctrica en el continente y una red de fibra óptica regional.

Trump dio una "pausa" de 90 días en los aranceles aplicados a decenas de países, excepto a China, a la que se los sube al 125% por haber tomado represalias.

Esto significa que deja el 10% universal que entró en vigor el sábado, en el que ya entraba la mayoría de los países latinoamericanos.

Canadá y México, sujetos a un régimen especial que implica tarifas del 25% (10% para los hidrocarburos canadienses) salvo los productos contemplados en el Tratado de Libre Comercio de América del Norte (T-MEC).

Una delegación de China encabezada por Qu Yuhui, el número dos de Asuntos Latinoamericanos de la cancillería, sostuvo encuentros bilaterales con delegados de 15 países en los últimos tres días.

A la delegación china se sumó Qiu Xiaoqi, enviado especial para América Latina y el Caribe.

Pekín propuso realizar una conferencia ministerial entre China y Celac el 13 de mayo en Pekín, que fue aprobada por los presidentes en esta cumbre.

Qu dijo que "Nuestro presidente Xi Jinping va a estar presente en la inauguración y va a discursar".

La cumbre culminó con la divulgación de una declaración conjunta suscrita por 30 países. Argentina, Paraguay y Nicaragua no la firmaron.

Por iniciativa de Brasil, la declaración indica que es "adecuado" que alguien de América Latina y el Caribe ocupe la Secretaría General de la ONU y destaca que "el cargo nunca ha sido ocupado por una mujer".

Lula indicó ante el plenario que "La Celac puede contribuir a restaurar la credibilidad de la ONU eligiendo a la primera mujer secretaria general de la organización".

A la cumbre asistieron también los presidentes de Bolivia, Luis Arce; Cuba, Miguel Díaz-Canel; Guatemala, Bernardo Arévalo; Uruguay, Yamandú Orsi; y Haití, Leslie Voltaire.

Díaz-Canel calificó como "chantaje vulgar" la amenaza de Estados Unidos de restringir visas a responsables de países que contratan médicos cubanos, y defendió sus misiones médicas en el exterior.

Asistieron a la cumbre los primeros ministros de Guyana, Mark Phillips, y San Vicente y las Granadinas, Ralph Gonsalves.

Por videoconferencia habló el presidente de Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro.

El presidente Trump soltó: “No quiero perjudicar a México… me gusta México, y, por cierto, creo que la nueva Presidenta es una Presidenta magnífica y una mujer fantástica… hemos tenido muchas conversaciones. Es muy elegante, una persona fantástica. Desde el 7 de marzo, México y Canadá enfrentan un arancel de 25 por ciento en la exportación de autos hacia EU y otro para el acero y el aluminio y en las latas de cerveza.

La presidenta Sheinbaum ha modificado radicalmente sus programas y políticas de seguridad frente a la exigencia del mandatario estadounidense de cortar el flujo de migrantes y de fentanilo hacia EU y en su combate a carteles.

Durante los dos últimos meses se han capturado las mayores dosis de fentanilo y cocaína dirigidas hacia EU, se han desmantelado unos 600 laboratorios del narco y capturado al mayor número de capos locales mientras se han entregado a lideres del narco para ser enjuiciados en EU.

La vicepresidenta de Colombia, Francia Márquez, indicó a su vez que hasta ahora, en América han llegado tres mujeres afrodescendientes a la vicepresidencia de sus países: Epsy Campbell Barr, de Costa Rica; Kamala Harris, en Estados Unidos, y ella.

title: El delegado del Gobierno pide a Moreno no entrar en "confrontación" a cuenta de los aranceles de Trump - (Published 19 hour(s), 2 minute(s) ago)
content: El delegado del Gobierno en Andalucía, Pedro Fernández, ha pedido al presidente de la Junta, Juanma Moreno, no entrar en "la confrontación sin más" sino trabajar para avanzar en la negociación entre ...
resumen:
El delegado del Gobierno en Andalucía, Pedro Fernández, ha pedido al presidente de la Junta, Juanma Moreno, no entrar en "la confrontación sin más" sino trabajar para avanzar en la negociación entre el Estado y las comunidades autónomas para las medidas para amortiguar la repercusión de los aranceles de Estados Unidos.

El presidente de la Junta de Andalucía, Juanma Moreno, ha calificado este viernes como "necesario el diálogo" en la negociación, pero de igual forma ha demandado al Gobierno que sea "leal" al reclamarle que "por debajo de la mesa no se negocie con otras fuerzas políticas, en este caso independentistas, otras opciones que le puedan favorecer a él".

Fernández, a preguntas de los periodistas en Playa Granada, en Motril, ha indicado que no puede "compartir en absoluto" este tipo de manifestaciones y se ha remitido a otras de la consejera de Economía, Carolina España, al hilo de la reunión del ministro del ramo, Carlos Cuerpo, con las comunidades autónomas sobre estas medidas.

Ponen de manifiesto, según el delegado del Gobierno en Andalucía, "la magnífica reunión que se produjo" con Cuerpo, este pasado jueves, y "el buen entendimiento que hubo, más allá de compartir o no el cien por cien de las medidas".

Ha resaltado en este contexto "el compromiso de mensualmente seguir reuniéndose para valorar cuál es la situación", su evolución y "el impacto" de la misma, así como para abordar estrategias de "internacionalización" de las empresas.

También ha hecho hincapié en el posicionamiento de que es "un tema absurdo hablar de reparto territorial de aquello que no dejan de ser préstamos", con "financiación por parte del Instituto de Crédito Oficial, por ejemplo", o "avales, que en definitiva hay que devolver". En este sentido, "no se puede repartir aquello que hay que pagar".

El fondo de la cuestión, según el delegado, es que existe la "capacidad de que todas las empresas de España, vinculadas especialmente a los sectores que se puedan ver más perjudicados, si persisten los aranceles", puedan acudir, sean del territorio que sean", en "igualdad de condiciones", a este tipo de ayudas, "que es lo que está aprobado".

title: China responde a Trump y elevará al 125% desde mañana los aranceles a productos estadounidenses - (Published 21 hour(s), 25 minute(s) ago)
content: Madrid/ El Gobierno de China ha decidido responder a la última subida de los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos a sus exportaciones elevando a partir de mañana al 125% la tarifa adicional aplicada ...
resumen:
El Gobierno de China ha decidido responder a la última subida de los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos a sus exportaciones elevando a partir de mañana al 125% la tarifa adicional aplicada sobre las mercancías estadounidenses importadas, de conformidad con la legislación de la República Popular China y los principios básicos del derecho internacional.

Pekín ha indicado que "si Estados Unidos continúa jugando con las cifras de los aranceles, China lo ignorará", advirtiendo de que, si Washington insiste en seguir violando sustancialmente los derechos e intereses de China, contraatacarán con firmeza y lucharán hasta el final.

Desde el Ministerio de Finanzas de China han señalado la "firme oposición" de China y la más enérgica condena a las "desmedidas" decisiones arancelarias unilaterales de Estados Unidos, asegurando que la reiterada imposición de aranceles anormalmente altos a China por parte de Estados Unidos "se ha convertido en un juego de números, sin relevancia económica práctica" y que "solo expondrá aún más el uso de los aranceles por parte de Estados Unidos como instrumento y arma para intimidar y coaccionar, convirtiéndose en una broma".

El portazo chino continuaba asegurando que "Estados Unidos debe asumir toda la responsabilidad", destacando que, bajo la presión de China, Estados Unidos ha suspendido temporalmente la imposición de elevados aranceles recíprocos a algunos de sus socios comerciales, lo que ha calificado de un "pequeño paso simbólico" que no cambia la "naturaleza" de Estados Unidos de buscar beneficios privados mediante el chantaje comercial.

También ha recordado la postura de Pekín para unas reacciones económicas y comerciales entre China y Estados Unidos sobre la base del beneficio mutuo porque "en una guerra comercial nadie gana" y el proteccionismo no tiene salida. "China está abierta a consultas con Estados Unidos, pero las amenazas y la presión no son la manera correcta de tratar con China", indició el portavoz chino.

El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, suspendió temporalmente por 90 días la implementación de nuevas medidas arancelarias, pero la tensión comercial se ha recrudecido. La Casa Blanca anunció un aumento arancelario de hasta el 145% sobre productos importados desde China, excluyéndola de la pausa aplicada a otras naciones. El gobierno chino impuso un arancel adicional del 125 % sobre importaciones estadounidenses valoradas en más de 143.000 millones de dólares.

El índice S&P 500 cierra esta semana con alta volatilidad. Tras un repunte del 9,5% el miércoles 9 de abril, cayó 3,5 % el jueves 10 y abrió el viernes 11 con una leve baja del 0,16%. El Dow Jones cae 0,30 % este viernes. El Nasdaq abrió este viernes con un alza del 0,17 % y acumula un avance semanal del 5,1 %.

1.  Nvidia: líder en el desarrollo de unidades de procesamiento gráfico (GPU). Sus acciones se cotizan en 109,71 dólares, con un crecimiento del 2 %.
2.  Microsoft: sus acciones se cotizan a 382,58 dólares, experimentando un alza del 0,32 %.
3.  Apple: sus acciones están a 192,88 dólares y presentan un incremento del 1,29 %.
4.  Amazon: sus acciones se cotizan a 179,70 dólares, con una leve caída del 0,84 %.
5.  Alphabet (Google): sus acciones se cotizan a 155,54 dólares, con un aumento del 1,78 %.

content: Los críticos podremos decir misa, pero de que la presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum ha seguido una estrategia acertada en su relación con Donald Trump, ni cómo negarlo. Mientras cientos de gobiernos y paíse ...
resumen: Durante la primera semana de aranceles de Trump, en México el peso frente al dólar amaneció sin grandes alteraciones y los mercados continuaron ofreciendo en abundancia sus productos, nadie fue despedido por las decisiones fiscales del mandatario estadounidense y la vida diaria de sus 130 millones de habitantes continuó con un sol esplendoroso. Los temas mediáticos fueron los del debate sobre madres buscadoras que se quejan de desatenciones gubernamentales, el de los miles de desaparecidos que ahora llaman la atención de la ONU, y el caso de la campaña adelantada de la senadora Andrea Chávez en Chihuahua y el desdén de la legisladora ante los señalamientos de la presidenta Sheinbaum. Los aranceles de Trump no han provocado el disparo de precios de ningún producto de importación o nacional. Para el mexicano promedio, nada, pues, de qué alarmarse. Las proyecciones de los analistas, los críticos, de que va a pasar esto y lo otro, son apenas una leve bruma en la opinión de los ciudadanos. Los males presagiados no llegan. Y sus amenazas se diluyen. Y mucho menos cuando de todos los puntos cardinales llegan reconocimientos y alabanzas a la estrategia de la presidenta mexicana en su reacción frente a Trump. El presidente Trump soltó: “No quiero perjudicar a México… me gusta México, y, por cierto, creo que la nueva Presidenta es una Presidenta magnífica y una mujer fantástica… hemos tenido muchas conversaciones. Es muy elegante, una persona fantástica. Y ha sido muy amable…. “No busco perjudicarlos, pero teníamos tres plantas automotrices en construcción en México y se dejaron de construir y ahora las construirán en Estados Unidos debido a los aranceles», indicó en una rueda de prensa en la Casa Blanca. Desde el 7 de marzo, México y Canadá enfrentan un arancel de 25 por ciento en la exportación de autos hacia EU y otro para el acero y el aluminio y en las latas de cerveza. La presidenta Sheinbaum ha modificado radicalmente sus programas y políticas de seguridad frente a la exigencia del mandatario estadounidense de cortar el flujo de migrantes y de fentanilo hacia EU y en su combate a cárteles. Durante los dos últimos meses se han capturado las mayores dosis de fentanilo y cocaína dirigidas hacia EU, se han desmantelado unos 600 laboratorios del narco y capturado al mayor número de capos locales mientras se han entregado a lideres del narco para ser enjuiciados en EU.

content: La Paz, 11 abr (EFE).- El colombiano Darío Mejía asumió este viernes, en la ciudad boliviana de La Paz, la secretaría Técnica del Fondo para el Desarrollo de los Pueblos Indígenas de América Latina y ...
resumen: El colombiano Darío Mejía asumió la secretaría Técnica del Fondo para el Desarrollo de los Pueblos Indígenas de América Latina y el Caribe (Filac) para el periodo 2025-2028, en la ciudad boliviana de La Paz. Mejía, indígena zenú, fue presentado en la sede del organismo en La Paz en un «acto de invocación» en la Residencia de la Embajada de España en Bolivia, con la presencia del embajador de Brasil, Luis Henrique Sobreira, y de Nicaragua, Elías Chévez, entre otros invitados. El Filac fue creado en 1992 en la II Cumbre Iberoamericana, es un mecanismo de diálogo entre los pueblos indígenas y los representantes de los Gobiernos de Belice, Bolivia, Brasil, Chile, Colombia, Cuba, Ecuador, España, Guatemala, Honduras, México, Nicaragua, Panamá, Paraguay, Perú, Portugal, Uruguay y Venezuela.

title: Markets Worry About Finding an Exit From Trump’s Trade Fight - (Published 18 hour(s), 24 minute(s) ago)
content: Investors are concerned about the continued escalation of the U.S.-China tariff battle — and the state of the president’s negotiating leverage.
resumen:
The trade battle intensifies: China raised its tariffs on U.S. imports, and Beijing called the Trump administration’s tariffs “a joke.” Tesla stopped taking orders in China for two models it imports from the U.S. The U.S. dollar and Treasuries are being battered. Chinese levies on U.S. goods will rise to 125 percent from 84 percent. The Trump administration placed 145 percent tariffs on imports from China and 10 percent tariffs on most other trade partners. The dollar is falling sharply again, having suffered its biggest drop against the euro in a decade. The 30-year Treasury bond is on track for its worst week since the 1980s, according to Deutsche Bank research. West Texas Intermediate, the U.S. oil benchmark, is trading around $60. JPMorgan Chase reported gains in its core consumer lending, investment banking and trading businesses for the first quarter. Jamie Dimon, the bank’s C.E.O., warned that “the economy is facing considerable turbulence.” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said on Thursday that he saw “nothing unusual” about the market swings. Simultaneous drops in the dollar, stocks and long-dated Treasury bonds are extreme, especially in the United States, and suggest a potentially larger capital flight away from U.S. financial assets, analysts noted. Bondholders remain wary, concerned about the inflationary effects of tariffs. Berenberg forecasts that the yield on the 10-year treasury note will rise to 4.8 percent, up from about 4.4 percent this morning. Investors appear to be worried about what’s next for the “Trump put.” Thursday’s market plunge seems tied in part to a growing belief that the only way for Trump to get out of this predicament is walk away from his fight altogether.

The House passes a Trump-endorsed budget blueprint. Elon Musk appears to drop his cost-cutting target again. In a cabinet meeting on Thursday, the billionaire said that his so-called Department of Government Efficiency anticipates cutting $150 billion in the 2026 fiscal year, which runs from October 2025 to September 2026. A White House official said $1 trillion remains the goal. More law firms near deals with Trump. The president told his cabinet that four or five firms were close to committing $125 million each to do pro bono work. Among those that have held talks with Trump advisers in recent days are Latham & Watkins, Kirkland & Ellis and Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. Republican lawmakers target the Ivy League over claims of price fixing. The Senate and House Judiciary committees began inquiries into the eight universities. The Trump administration is looking to place Columbia University under a consent decree.

Senator Elizabeth Warren has sent a letter to the S.E.C. asking the agency to investigate whether President Trump violated securities laws while reversing course on his global tariffs on Wednesday. During a period of intensely volatile trading, Mr. Trump wrote on social media, “THIS IS A GREAT TIME TO BUY!!!” Hours later, he announced a 90-day pause on many of his reciprocal tariffs, sending the S&P 500 soaring more than 7 percent in just minutes. Warren wants to know who knew what, and when. Representative Maxine Waters sent a letter to the S.E.C. and the U.S. Government Accountability Office on Thursday. Of particular concern to her was a spike in trading of call options — bets that a stock will rise — in the period directly leading up to Trump’s announcement of the pause on tariffs. Financial experts said they saw no immediate proof of insider trading.

U.S. markets sold off on Thursday as investors feared further uncertainty around President Trump’s tariffs and concerns about an economic war with China. The only way to stop the broad levies on U.S. trading partners is through the courts, Paul Sracic said. Four Republican senators voted with Democrats last week to pass a measure that would block Trump’s tariffs on Canadian goods. Seven Republican senators have signed on to another bipartisan bill that would give Congress a 60-day window to approve new tariffs imposed by the president. On Thursday, Senator Lisa Murkowski called on her fellow lawmakers to reassert their authority over tariffs. The Constitution grants Congress, not the president, control over levies. The Supreme Court has previously ruled that the executive branch cannot claim authority to decide “major questions” of economic and political significance unless Congress has clearly delegated it. The libertarian New Civil Liberties Alliance filed a lawsuit last week over the Trump’s tariffs on Chinese goods. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce is also said to be considering a legal challenge to Trump’s global tariffs. The Retail Industry Leaders Association began planning to sue over the tariffs, but put the efforts on hold. The editorial board of The Wall Street Journal has also pointed out specific limits on Trump’s power to apply tariffs. Trump is relying on a 1977 law that gives the president expanded powers during an emergency. In imposing tariffs on China in February, Trump cited what he said was a surge of illegal drugs from the country; on the worldwide tolls, he called the U.S. trade deficit “an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and economy of the United States.” In its lawsuit, the New Civil Liberties Alliance argues that the 1977 law does not grant the president the authority to enact broad tariffs.

Prada agreed to buy Versace for $1.38 billion. Thinking Machines Lab, the artificial intelligence start-up founded by the former OpenAI executive Mira Murati, has reportedly raised its fund-raising target to around $2 billion. Trump administration officials have discussed revoking migrants’ lawfully obtained Social Security numbers to pressure them to leave the country.

title: How This Trade War Is Different From All Other Trade Wars - (Published 17 hour(s), 29 minute(s) ago)
content: By acting on his own, President Trump has broken with more than 200 years of U.S. history in which Congress set the direction of trade policy.
resumen: President Trump has broken with more than 200 years of U.S. history in which Congress set the direction of trade policy. The first skirmishes in a trade war have begun. Douglas Irwin, a Dartmouth economic historian, said that what we were experiencing was way outside the historical norm. One man alone has risked the first global trade war since the 1930s by raising tariffs to levels unseen for more than a century. The president’s actions represent a “big break with history.” Mr. Trump announced a 90-day pause for some of the highest tariffs on Wednesday, while keeping a 10 percent base line for virtually all imports from around the world. The consequences include the possibility of a global recession and geopolitical shifts. Until now, it had always taken decades of consensus building to bend the trajectory of trade policy, Professor Irwin said. When the country changed course in earlier times, Congress played the dominant role. Even when it began delegating authority to negotiate trade deals to the president in the 1930s, Congress set the direction of U.S. tariffs: downward. Now, it’s unquestionably the president who has taken the United States on a new and hazardous path. In the past, wars provided the impetus for change. The Civil War and World War I led to higher tariffs enacted by Congress after lengthy discussion. Tariffs began falling in the Franklin D. Roosevelt administration, and with some exceptions, including the Biden and first Trump administrations, they remained fairly low. In a peacetime economy, with full employment, 4 percent, one person, the president, is radically changing the direction of U.S. trade policy. Stock markets have been swirling — falling for days, then leaping in delight on Wednesday at news that some of the U.S. tariffs had been delayed. The benchmark S&P 500 stock index rose 9.5 percent. By Thursday, the enthusiasm had ebbed. The S&P 500 fell 3.5 percent for the day, only to rise 1.8 percent on Friday. Economists view the direction of tariff policy as wrongheaded and profoundly dangerous. The president’s series of tariff announcements had set off expectations of sharply rising prices for households and businesses alike, raising a strong possibility that a spreading global trade war could send the U.S. economy spiraling into a recession. After the president said he was delaying some tariffs, Goldman Sachs dropped its forecast that a recession was likely. Goldman prognosis was bleak: “We are reverting to our previous non-recession base-line forecast with G.D.P. growth of 0.5 percent and a 45 percent probability of recession.” China has retaliated with tariffs of its own. U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods had reached 145 percent; China reciprocated with tariffs on U.S. products, raising them on Friday to 125 percent. Negotiations were underway with many countries — but not China — the Treasury secretary, Scott Bessent, said. The European Union said it would delay its plans for retaliation for 90 days. Congressional resistance to the Trump trade policy has begun, with a mainly Democratic effort in the Senate to end the “national emergency” that the president declared as the legal justification for his tariffs. Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution expressly reserves for Congress the power to impose tariffs. Congressional dominance over trade policy shifted substantially after the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930. Dale Copeland, a political scientist at the University of Virginia, said the tariffs were major factors in a dire turn in world history. Ed Clissold, senior U.S. strategist at Ned Davis Research, said the geopolitical implications of rising tariffs needed to be studied closely. Emily Bowersock Hill, chief executive of Bowersock Capital Partners, said that without checks on his behavior, Mr. Trump was making erratic geopolitical moves.

title: China impone aranceles del 125% a productos de EE. UU. y aviva la tensión comercial - (Published 13 hour(s), 37 minute(s) ago)
content: El gobierno chino fijó en 125% los gravámenes a mercancías estadounidenses. La medida entra en vigor el 12 de abril y se acompañará de una demanda ante la OMC.
resumen: China impone aranceles del 125% a productos de Estados Unidos. La medida entra en vigor el 12 de abril y se acompañará de una demanda ante la OMC. El Gobierno chino anunció que subirá los aranceles a los productos de Estados Unidos al 125%, profundizando aún más la guerra comercial entre las dos mayores economías del mundo. La Comisión Arancelaria del Consejo de Estado de Pekín afirmó que la imposición por parte de Estados Unidos de aranceles anormalmente altos a China viola de forma grave las normas comerciales internacionales, las leyes económicas básicas y el sentido común. Pekín presentará una demanda ante la Organización Mundial del Comercio (OMC) por la última ronda de aranceles de Trump. Donald Trump anunció el 9 de abril una pausa de 90 días en los aranceles que acababa de imponer a 60 socios comerciales, excepto a China. Washington mantiene aranceles mínimos del 10% y recargos aduaneros del 25% sobre el acero, el aluminio y los automóviles. En cuanto a China, los aranceles sobre sus importaciones ascienden en su totalidad al 145%. El presidente chino, Xi Jinping, urgió a la Unión Europea a “resistir juntas” al “hostigamiento”. El comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcovic, mantendrá el 14 de abril en Washington reuniones con altos funcionarios estadounidenses para “evitar una escalada” de tensiones comerciales. La presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, advirtió que tienen a disposición un “amplio abanico de contramedidas”. El presidente estadounidense volvió a amenazar el jueves a México con “aranceles y quizás incluso sanciones” hasta que cumpla un tratado de 1944 y “le dé a Texas el agua que le debe”. Trump impuso aranceles del 25% a los productos mexicanos por considerar que México no combate eficazmente el tráfico de fentanilo.

title: Índice iPhone y su relación con otros productos que pueden subir de precio por aranceles de Trump hacia China - (Published 12 hour(s), 48 minute(s) ago)
content: Estudios internacionales refieren que el precio del iPhone se encarecerá en las próximas semanas por las tasas a la importación que impuso Estados Unidos a China, país en donde se fabrican varios ...
resumen:
El precio del iPhone se encarecerá en las próximas semanas debido a las tasas de importación impuestas por Estados Unidos a China, país donde se fabrican varios de sus componentes.

La firma Apple fabrica la mayoría de sus productos en China, país al que Trump ha impuesto altos aranceles, la última actualización indica que los elevó a un 145%.

Estudios de UBS Investment Research y Euronews estimaron que el precio del iPhone aumentará entre 43% y 56%.

Esto incluye dispositivos electrónicos —tabletas, computadoras portátiles y otros productos tecnológicos— que se ensamblan en China, además de electrodomésticos —refrigeradoras y lavadoras—.

Muchos componentes provienen del gigante asiático, refirió Rodolfo Pérez, experto de la firma EY.

Las empresas enfrentan el desafío de absorber costos, distribuirlos en la cadena de suministro o trasladarlos al consumidor, lo que podría aumentar precios y reducir la demanda a corto plazo.

Guatemala, sin imponer aranceles recíprocos, podría beneficiarse negociando acuerdos comerciales con aranceles reducidos o diversificando sus fuentes de importación.

A nivel empresarial, la diversificación de proveedores y optimización de procesos productivos, mediante metodologías como "Treasure Hunting", donde en un modelo ágil se pueden identificar “victorias rápidas” de optimización que pueden aprovecharse en tiempos de incertidumbre, recomendó el especialista.

Los consumidores podrían enfrentar incrementos en precios, afectando su poder adquisitivo y contribuyendo a la inflación.

Será impactada la totalidad de bienes producida, ensamblada o elaborada en China y que tenga como destino el mercado de EE. UU., según Ana Lucía Santacruz, socia de impuestos y comercio exterior, y Ludy Lima, gerente de comercio exterior de la firma Deloitte Guatemala.

El aumento de aranceles en bienes provenientes de China, con destino al mercado estadounidense, afecta diversas categorías como maquinaria, juguetes, electrónicos, electrodomésticos, textiles, baterías y telecomunicaciones.

Entre el 13% y 17% de las importaciones a EE. UU. en 2024 provinieron de China, destacando que los productos electrónicos y eléctricos abarcan entre el 25% y 30% de dichas exportaciones.

Las estrategias para las empresas varían según sus márgenes de beneficio, por ejemplo, aquellas con márgenes amplios podrían absorber los costos, buscando aumentar participación de mercado, mientras que empresas con márgenes reducidos podrían optar por trasladar parte de los costos a los consumidores, dependiendo de su viabilidad financiera.

Si los costos son trasladados al consumidor, el impacto incluye menor poder adquisitivo, reducción en consumo y posibles oportunidades para productores de países con aranceles más bajos.

En EE. UU., se anticipa un incremento de la inflación y desaceleración del crecimiento económico.

En China, esto podría resultar en una caída en exportaciones, recortes de producción y disminución del PIB, concluyeron las especialistas de Deloitte.
